page.title: 01A Devon farming Valley
page.content: The roman metalled road ending at Exeter, western trafic had to follow the ancient tracks, one of them the ridgeway over the northern hills of the valley which horizontally divides this block, four miles from Exeter. The later toll road droped 150 fet to the valley bottom, was promoted to A30, but has just been robed of its traffic by a double-track double-caarriae way, formal and fatureless. Roman, Saxon and Norman would have classified the valley land just as it is now good grass land, green throught the year, corn on some tops, and its noble curves edges by a multitude of deciduous trees in lines or small copses. Ten farms are listed on the maps, but outside some of the brightly maintained and extended houses, a Range Rover or Jag sugests the gentleman armer whose hunters are
